column2: I don't want Amber Heard anywhere near my family.
column44: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.
column54: Washington Post Needs to Remove Amber Heard's OP-ED!

column2: It is obvious that Amber Heard has committed perjury in three countries, and under oath in three courtrooms! A jury of her peers in the US found her to have defamed Johnny Depp and she is guilty of malicious lies! A very public apology would be nice, but the actually redemption needed from the ACLU would be to drop request for documentation charges, and the immediate removal of the Op-Ed!

column2:
As a survivor, I stand with survivors. I stand with Johnny Depp. Abuse has no gender. Abusers like Heard should have no mercy nor respite because she is continuing the farce completely without remorse or hesitation. She deserves zero respect and chose to forgo her own chance at any dignity by sibling down on her lies and slanderous claims. I see only narcissism and no remorse in the way she perpetrated not only abusive and harmful behavior on Mr Depp's person and mentality, but also for continuing the abuse through proxies and defamation of his character and livelihood. 
She was a mediocre actor at best and unbelievable (ask the jury) at worst. All she has to offer entertainment is her looks and unremarkable acting talent. Hollywood already has tons of those. May she slide back into the mists of forgettable roles and obscurity that she crawled out of briefly, by the grace of Johnny Depp.
Justice for Johnny

column2: Amber Heard is a LIAR !!!!
column44: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.
column54: Washington Post Needs to Remove Amber Heard's OP-ED!

column2: Because Amber Heard is a proven liar.
column44: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.
column54: Washington Post Needs to Remove Amber Heard's OP-ED!

column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.

column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.
column54: Washington Post Needs to Remove Amber Heard's OP-ED!

column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.
column54: Washington Post Needs to Remove Amber Heard's OP-ED!

column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.

column44: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.
column54: Washington Post Needs to Remove Amber Heard's OP-ED!

column44: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.
column54: Washington Post Needs to Remove Amber Heard's OP-ED!

column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.

column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.

column51: Petition to Remove the OP-ED Amber Heard wrote from the Washington Post!
column52:
Now that Ms. Heard was found liable on all three counts for defaming Johnny Depp in the Washington Post op-ed titled “I spoke up against sexual violence—and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change", the online article should be removed.

It is unfair to Johnny Depp to have this article remain online when it was proven in a US Court of Law to hold false and defamatory statements made with malice toward Mr. Depp.

A jury found Ms. Heard liable on all three counts (see below) for making false, defamatory, and malice statements about Mr. Depp, and yet the Washington Post has not removed the online article.

1. “I spoke up against sexual violence and faced our culture’s wrath. That has to change.”

2. “Then two years ago, I became a public figure representing domestic abuse, and I felt the full force of our culture’s wrath for women who speak out.”

3. “I had the rare vantage point of seeing, in real time, how institutions protect men accused of abuse.” 

The Washington Post has only made an editor’s note of the outcome of the trial but has not taken any responsibility or action to remove the article which was written by the abuser.
column54: Washington Post Needs to Remove Amber Heard's OP-ED!
